ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed no knowledge, skills, or insights from this course aside from the insight that I would never take another class with Professor Fahmy again or even recommend his courses to another student. I also learned the IMMENSE value of TFs- this course did not have any TFs, and it was a flaming garbage pile of confusion and frustration.

The courses started with an introduction to the innate and adaptive immune systems, followed by discussions of how researchers are attempting to modulate the immune system through thoughtfully-designed therapies. We spent a lot of time discussing vaccines and T cell activation.

Learned about the immune system and ways vaccines are made (felt very relevant in light of pandemic). Didn't really learn much during class since Prof Fahmy was often late and each class was disorganized and a bit all over the place. But in the lecture summaries/guides that provided a ton of notes (which could have been way clearer and concise), we actually learned about the material.

I gained a lot of knowledge about the methodology of the immune system, what has been discovered so far, and how it has been applied to improve quality of life. I also gained a lot of insight into the development of vaccines and understanding of some of the measures that have been taken in our struggle against the covid viruses.
I learned more about the immune system and vaccines which became very interesting during the pandemic.

I learned some about Immunology and vaccinations but overall was disappointed by the breadth of knowledge I took away from this course. There were a lot of interesting topics introduced but none were properly covered in a way that enabled proper learning or understanding.
I learned a lot about the immune system and we also discussed vaccines, immunity pretty in depth (given that its so relevant nowadays).

Knowledge: Immune System, and solutions that are being proposed that can address immunological issues! 

Skills: How to deliver presentations, how to learn for the knowledge rather than for the grade

Insights:

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The greatest weakness of this course is the professor. Immunoengineering as a field is incredible, dynamic, and at the forefront of so many new medical discoveries. In theory, I would have absolutely loved this class, but it was completely ruined by Professor Fahmy. He is disorganized, unclear, and did not follow the syllabus in any way. If it is possible to have immunoengineering be taught by another professor, please switch the professor. Or at the very least, please REQUIRE him to hire a TF. This subject matter is so fascinating, and it deserved to be delivered well, by a competent professor.
so incredibly disorganized

Strengths: Interesting topics, low workload, easy grading, prof readily available to meet in office hours, interesting final project
Weaknesses: unorganized (prof rarely posted lecture slides or grades), long tangents in class (didnt ever know what we were supposed to know), readings posted last-minute (such as the day before class or exams), overly complicated grading protocols, overall we didn't cover that much material
The class could be improved if the prof stays on schedule and posts lecture slides/notes after each class

Strengths: interesting info when you look past all the flaws of this course

Weaknesses: Fahmy is incredibly unreliable. Doesn't send back or grade anything until weeks or months later (as I write this, I still have not received graded assignments from months ago). Professor changed the date of the midterm, the day it was supposed to be administered. Terrible at communicating and responding to emails. The classes were all over the place. Homework assignments took FOREVER and since we didn't really learn anything in class, we had to spend hours looking though his notes which were so unclear.

The course imparted a lot of knowledge that was very relevant to issues happening around us. It also included a fun project. The structure of the course and the knowledge it imparts is great but I'm hoping that in the future course materials will be posted promptly.
The professor is all over the place but the class has some very interesting topics.

The organization was atrocious. The lectures were impossible to follow. The midterm was a complete mess. The grading was inconsistent. The professor was impossible to reach or get in touch with. All of these things would have to be completely changed in order for me to recommend this course to any student.

The course itself is very interesting but Professor Fahmy is incredibly disorganized. Hes very clearly passionate about what he teaches but the issue arises when grades are posted weeks if not months later, the material for class is poster right before or not at all or he changes the midterm several times. This course would be made 100 times better with a TF.
Strengths: Material is very interesting, you will definitely get an A. Weaknesses: Course is very very disorganized. Professor does not use TAs and sometimes it is very had to get ahold of him.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments:
I would never recommend this course to another student (unless taught by a professor other than Professor Fahmy). 

I should have known not to take this course when we still hadn't received any sort of syllabus by the second week of classes. When we did finally receive the syllabus, it was meaningless, as Professor Fahmy did not follow it whatsoever. Deadlines were unclear, assignments were given completely at random, and the entire course was chaos. At the beginning of the term, Professor Fahmy explained to us that he did not want to have a TF for the course because he wanted as much face-to-face interaction with students as possible. In theory, great! Love a hands-on professor. In practice, absolutely terrible. Professor Fahmy gave all students his cellphone number as well as email so we would have multiple ways to contact him- again, great in theory. I NEVER received a response to ANY text or email sent to Professor Fahmy. Whether it was asking a clarifying question on the material or trying to get my final project idea approved, he never once answered a single communication I sent him, and this was the same for most classmates. If you are going to refuse to have a TF, you need to be able to be contacted! 

Also, if you refuse to have a TF, you need to be able to design problem sets, give them to students, and grade them in a timely manner. Per the syllabus, we were supposed to have one problem set a week- standard stuff. Instead, we were assigned 1 on 9/14 due 9/21, 2 due 10/12, 3 on 10/13 due 10/18, and 4 on 11/28 due 12/2. Problem sets 3 and 4 STILL have not been graded, and today is December 12th. He gives no warnings for when he will actually give an assignment, and as you can see from the dates, does not even consistently give a full week for completing an assignment. 

Let's get into the midterm: we were supposed to have a take-home exam given to us on 10/19 (the Tuesday before fall break). 2 hours before the exam was supposed to be posted, we received an email that the exam would not be posted because Professor Fahmy was having dental surgery. Surgery sucks, and I feel bad for him, but he had had this surgery planned for months- he could have planned when to have the exam around this, instead of intending for the exam to be THE DAY OF HIS SURGERY and canceling the exam at the last minute. He rescheduled the exam for 10/28, the Thursday after fall break and told us he would be converting it to an IN-PERSON instead of take home exam. Giving us a little over a week to study, the week of which was supposed to be a BREAK, he swapped the whole format of the test. Two days before the test, he reversed again, saying it would be take home. This, understandably, caused a lot of anxiety, especially since he was recovering from surgery and no one could reach him to ask any questions.

Further side effect of his surgery: the Tuesday immediately after break (10/26), he showed up to class seemingly high as a kite on post-surgery medications. He gave us a handout that was supposed to be an analogy for T cell recognition of antigen-presenting cells... but the T cells were a bunch of cartoons of Donald Trump's head attached to a rollerblade?! And the rollerblade was skating around the United States trying to find another rollerblade of hands holding out food?! It was more incoherent than usual and frankly, bizarre and a bit alarming, especially with the punctuation of him repeatedly slapping the projector screen to make his points.

In addition to the total lack of professionalism and clarity surrounding any of the assignments or the midterm, Professor Fahmy consistently shows up to class 10 or more minutes late. It is disrespectful of student time. Furthermore, Professor Fahmy would disparage the idea of COVID-19 booster shots in class, saying he believed it would make us less immune rather than more immune, but he failed to send us any papers or scientific backing to support this belief.
no. its not a hard class but the disorganization can be very frustrating

I would probably not recommend this course to another student unless you are prepared for a chaotic but easily graded class. The lack of organization caused unnecessary stress, and the topics could have been learned quicker by directly reading the textbook or research papers.

Prof Fahmy is a really great person and clearly very smart, but a terrible professor. He is not meant to instruct. Maybe he is great at having conversations and engaging in intellectual discussion, but he cannot teach, stick to a schedule or ever respond to emails on time.... I would therefore not recommend this class to any student.
This course was a great wealth of knowledge regarding the covid situation and other health related problems. You will appreciate the knowledge gained.
Yes the class is very interesting and the professor typically grades fairly.

I would not in the state that it was taught. The material is promising but everything about the execution of this course is horrible. The class did not follow the syllabus, there was no educational organization to topics, the lecture was a complete waste of time because it was impossible to follow. The lecture notes were very helpful but did not at all reflect the knowledge gained in class. Nearly everything I learned was learned by reading the post-lecture notes which made me feel that attending class was overall a waste of time.

While the Professor is incredibly understanding, I would only recommend this course if a TF is provided. The organization is dismal and takes away from the actual learning (which is very interesting material, to be honest).
Yes, because the material is very very interesting. However, be prepared for a class that is very disorganized.
